title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act through a special message to Congress within 3 days of enactment. The proposed rescission cannot be repeated under this section or section 1012. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority through a special message to Congress, specifying details as required by law. Procedures for expedited consideration are outlined, including the introduction of a draft bill or joint resolution within a specified timeframe. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority through a special message to Congress. If a bill or joint resolution is not introduced within a specified timeframe, any Member of the House may introduce it. The bill or joint resolution is then referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it without substantive revision within a certain timeframe. If the committee fails to do so, it is automatically discharged, and the bill is placed on the calendar for consideration. A vote on final passage must be taken in the House before the close of the session. The bill or joint resolution shall be placed on the appropriate calendar for consideration. A vote on final passage must be taken in the House before the close of the 10th calendar day of continuous session after its introduction. If agreed to, the bill is engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress. A bill or joint resolution must be referred to the Committee on Appropriations of the House it is transmitted to, reported without substantive revision, and voted on for final passage within 10 days of continuous session. Failure to report within this timeframe results in automatic discharge from consideration. The joint resolution must be voted on for final passage within 10 days of continuous session after being transmitted to the House. Motion to proceed to consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section in the House of Representatives is highly privileged and not debatable. In the House of Representatives, a motion to consider a bill or joint resolution under this section is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill or joint resolution is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Appeals on procedural decisions related to the bill or joint resolution are decided without debate. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consider a bill or joint resolution under this section is privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill or joint resolution, along with any debatable motions and appeals, is limited to 10 hours. Debate in the Senate on a bill or joint resolution under this section, and all debatable motions and appeals, shall not exceed 10 hours. Time divided between majority and minority leaders. Debate on any debatable motion limited to 1 hour, divided between mover and bill manager. Additional time may be allotted by leaders on bill passage. The manager of the bill or joint resolution can control time during debate. Amendments are not allowed, and any rescinded budget authority must be made available for obligation. The House of Representatives or the Senate cannot suspend the application of subsections. Any rescinded budget authority must be available for obligation after the bill is defeated. Definitions for appropriation Act and continuity of a session are provided. The continuity of a session of Congress is only broken by an adjournment sine die. Days when either House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days are excluded in the calculation of continuous session periods. Special messages transmitted during a Congress are deemed to have been sent on the first day of the next Congress if the last session adjourns before 10 days of continuous session. Rulemaking powers under Section 904 of the Act are amended by adding references to sections 1013 and 1018. The amendment to Section 904 of the Act includes adding references to sections 1013 and 1018. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1011 and 1015 of the Act. Section 1015 of the Act is amended to include references to sections 1012, 1013, and 1014. Subsection (e)(2) is also modified to reflect these changes. Section 1016 of the Act is amended to include references to sections 1012, 1013, and 1014. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act. "Sec. 1013. Expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions."
